title: Friday, 7th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Welcome

PM11:01am

Beautiful day in London

11:01 am
PM11:01am

So we'll stick indoors with the screens

PM11:01am

So I keep reading about this supposed bond market rout

PM11:02am

And how it's all going to spill over into equities

11:02 am
PM11:02am

And kill the rich and stuff

PM11:03am

Have you noticed the generalised market atrocity Bryce?

BE11:04am

I've noticed a generalised atrophy. Not the other thing.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Well, i tell you

PM11:04am

Now it's a "bond wipeout"

PM11:04am

And it's coming to get equities, apparently

11:04 am
PM11:04am

https://www.bloomb...her-rates-can-hurt

PM11:05am

Is the bond rout over? You ain’t seen nothing yet and stock investors should take note.

The global equity rally that’s repeatedly shrugged off rising geopolitical uncertainty now faces a new test: the apparent certainty of higher borrowing costs. The spike in bond yields is just getting started, according to legendary fixed-income investor Jeffrey Gundlach. For Ray Dalio at the world’s largest hedge fund, the era of central-bank stimulus is now over.

PM11:05am

This Jeffrey Gundlach

11:05 am
PM11:05am

the legendary Jeffrey Gundlach

PM11:05am

We've clocked him before, i think

PM11:06am

Ah yes

11:05 am
PM11:06am

He can be our pic for today

PM11:06am

PM11:06am

Please use the sharing tools found via the email icon at the top of articles. Copying articles to share with others is a breach of FT.com T&Cs and Copyright Policy. Email licensing@ft.com to buy additional rights. Subscribers may share up to 10 or 20 articles per month using the gift article service. More information can be found at https://www.ft.com/tour.
https://www.ft.com...9ac32c284?mhq5j=e2

“It’s not going to happen,” Mr Gundlach says, definitively. “People like to complain, they like to say what’s wrong but then when it comes down to actually pulling the lever they sit there and they say, ‘what exactly am I doing here, what is going to happen?’ The devil you know is better than the devil you don’t know. Look at what happened with Scotland. People aren’t going to pull a lever for Brexit, so I don’t even think that’s worth considering in the present time.”

11:06 am
PM11:06am

https://www.ft.com...9ac32c284?mhq5j=e2

PM11:06am

That's a bit cruel of me

PM11:07am

Quite a few of us got Brexit vote wrong

11:07 am
PM11:07am

https://www.bloomb...-rush-for-the-exit

PM11:08am

This rush for the exit...

PM11:09am

Still, let's look at the damage to stocks

undefined

PM11:09am

How far has the Footsie fallen Bryce?

PM11:09am

How rattled are we?

BE11:10am

It hasn't. As is tradition when you set the tone with a whack of bleak and forboding top-down stuff, the FTSE has barely budged.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Up 0.01% on my screen.

BE11:11am

With all sorts of silly things happening below that relative calm.

PM11:11am

Sterling plunge tempers bond rout contagion

You mean all this random bid speculation?

11:11 am

I mean, this Centrica bid's gonna be awesome!

BE11:11am

Particularly for Stephen Pusey and Margherita Della Valle, Centrica non-execs, who bought shares on June 26.

https://www.invest...1706271415013186J/

hahahaha

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 210.78, up 8.88 (+4.40%), High: 213.00, Low: 209.00, Volume: 27.21m
BE11:12am

The rumour here -- and I use the word "rumour" in its loosest possible sense -- is of an (unidentified) "strategic buyer" and an (unnamed) "consortium of infrastructure buyers from Kuwait/Singapore/Canada", willing to pay “as high as 300p”.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Maybe they'll prove to be clairvoyant

BE11:12am

And I mean, okay .......... so people familiar with Centrica's thinking have indicated to us that it's rubbish.

BE11:12am

And anyone waiting for a statement either way is likely to have a very long wait.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

It's possible that people familiar with things just don't know, I guess.

BE11:13am

Unidentified strategic buyers and unnamed consortiums of infrastructure buyers from Kuwait/Singapore/Canada might be planning stuff on the down-low, perhaps.

BE11:13am

Though I guess could turn to precedent here. Such as .....

BE11:15am

PM11:15am

There must be one in there from a one of us?!

BE11:15am

11:15 am
PM11:15am

hehehe

BE11:15am

There are many from us. This was just a skim of the surface.

BE11:16am

Anyway, Jefferies don't like the sound of it.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

The article claims that potential buyers interest is driven by Centrica's strong cash flow generation, historically low share price and receding regulatory risk in the UK retail energy market. We would note two points: (i) such funds are typically interested in regulated infrastructure assets (e.g. electricity grids) whereas Centrica's core business is its UK retail business which continues to face competitive pressures. Also, regulatory uncertainty remains relatively high. Even though Ofgem's proposals suggest that the likelihood of an industry-wide energy price cap is low, the Energy Secretary noted in parliament recently that he could still legislate for a stronger price cap if Ofgem doesn't go far enough. Centrica trades on 2017 P/E of 13.5x with 10% FCF yield.

BE11:16am

And Barclays.

BE11:17am

Given the current political/regulatory risk to UK domestic energy retail (even though this threat appears to have moderated from potentially worst case scenarios, with greater than 40% of CNA NOPAT coming from the area the company remains highly exposed to ongoing uncertainties) and weak E&P, we believe it would be potentially high risk to launch a takeover bid at this time, though the cash generation of (many of) Centrica’s existing businesses does hold attractions.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

I saw someone senior from Centrica just last week. They seemed rather more distracted by local political developments rather than a potential bid

PM11:18am

ie -- they felt under political siege, not corporate

BE11:18am

Also, Merrill.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The article seems to misunderstand Centrica's asset-light, unregulated business model. We find it questionable and therefore advocate caution.

BE11:18am

....... Hm.

PM11:19am

Er, which actual article are they referring to -- or are we glossing over that?

11:19 am
BE11:19am

I was weighing up whether to link to it. I'm not sure whether it's wise.

PM11:20am

Fine, if in doubt gloss over

BE11:20am

Centrica still up 4.5%, though, and taking the sector with it.

11:20 am
SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,479, up 26.19 (+1.80%), High: 1,480, Low: 1,459, Volume: 924.24k

This is Markets Live

BE11:25am

(I do occasionally get buyside folk -- mostly US folk -- contacting me to try and get info on how I good I view other hacks. I tend to tell them to go away, which is my default position. Monetising it wouldn't be a bad idea though.)

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Anyway, I was talking about the utils push from various quarters.

PM11:27am

(Centrica -- virtual short term trading Sell at 210p )

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Here's Citi .............

BE11:27am

We have become more constructive on the UK waters. Contrary to the negative sentiment on the UK water utilities and having had a more negative stance on these names in the recent past, we are becoming more constructive on the valuation of these names following the recent sell-off. We see Severn Trent, Pennon and United Utilities’ shares as broadly fairly valued and continue to rate them as Neutral. United Utilities is our preferred water utility on valuation grounds. If de-rating were to continue, we believe these names could become more attractive on fundamentals.

BE11:28am

HSBC moves Severn up to hold .....

11:28 am
BE11:29am

.... in a note saying to "expect virtue signalling next week" from Ofwat....

BE11:29am

There's also Morgan Stanley, and Merrill, and others. But I'm bored now.

11:30 am

Have you seen this WPP note from Exane?

Hold on, will find an alternative.

PM11:30am

Feels like Mifid II planning -- Exane selling research as a platform service etc

11:32 am
WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,548, down 62 (-3.85%), High: 1,589, Low: 1,548, Volume: 3.06m
BE11:33am

............... Seeing if I can open the note with Opera's embedded PDF viewer.

BE11:33am

Yes! That worked.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

....... oh, hang on. No it didn't. Bear with.

BE11:35am

In two parallel reports addressing the weak growth of ad stocks, we conclude that the issues faced by both Broadcasters and Agencies could be bigger and more protracted than many believe.

BE11:35am

The titles here are Deafening tick of the Digital clock: part 1 and part 2.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Sounds interesting

BE11:36am

It's interesting enough to be a split, like Angels in America or like that Harry Potter play.

BE11:37am

54 pages of that. Let me see if the broadcasters one is equally .... whatever.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Ad growth has been anaemic in the past four quarters
Ad growth in key European TV markets has been increasingly disappointing in the past four quarters
and decorrelated from near-peak PMIs. TV Ad growth seems 300-500bp too low since Q3 16.
Who’s the culprit? Google and Facebook bite, Consumer Brands under pressure
We show that Facebook’s and Google’s expansion is likely at the expense of TV, as their video
products are now a direct alternative to TV whilst print budgets are too small to feed their growth.
Key FMCG categories are cutting ad budgets and accelerating their shift online. Note that the last
time we saw such a decorrelation in 2007/08, ad growth slowed ahead of leading indicators.
New forecasts materially lower – and it could be just the beginning
We cut our 2017 ad growth forecasts, which still imply a modest rebound in H2. We also expect a
weaker 2018-19 (c.1%+ vs 2–3%). This leads to broad, sometimes double-digit EPS cuts for 2018-
19. Structural drivers cited above are not going away and cyclical risk will likely rise in the next 1-2
years. We see a rising risk of TV ad growth flattening or even dipping into negative territory. We
expect most broadcaster to cut their advertising outlook at H1 results
Trading only just below the market, with possibly much greater earning risks
TV’s PE is at a 5% discount to the market, after a gradual 15-year de-rating. Yet rel. EPS has eased
only recently despite higher structural and cyclical risk. We are 4–6% below consensus for 2018–19e.
Investment conclusion: not many places to hide – downgrading A3, MSE, Pro7 and MS
The lower digital market share in Southern Europe gives FTAs there a false sense of security; they
are the least diversified. We turn Underperform on MS, MSE and A3. France has some potential for
short-term upgrades (Macron effect?) – TF1 is our sole Outperform. ITV (=) is likely hit the most/the
earliest but is cheap with a content hedge. Pro7 (= vs +) should be more resilient but is not cheap.

BE11:38am

Sorry for the lumpy formatting. That one's 57 pages.

BE11:39am

For the rest, go speak to Exane and become a customer of their Mifidii compliant RaaS product.

11:38 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 177.70, down 4.2 (-2.31%), High: 181.50, Low: 177.60, Volume: 3.83m
undefined
BE11:40am

In terms of stuff mentioned on the right ...........

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Aveva. Dull trading statement, as expected.

BE11:40am

Given its AGM is only a month after results.

AVEVA Group PLC (AVV:LSE): Last: 1,980, up 5 (+0.25%), High: 2,033, Low: 1,975, Volume: 200.01k
11:40 am
PM11:41am

Everything in line with expectations

BE11:42am

Part of issue with the noise around Aveva right now is previous experience, it occurs.

BE11:42am

As in, when they were in talks with Schneider over a reverse takeover.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

It was widely rumoured, primarily by us FWIW, that Aveva and Schneider were talking.

BE11:43am

But it seems the Panel let it slide because it was a reverse, and saying anything meant Aveva had to be suspended.

BE11:44am

Management were asked some awkward questions about false markets immediately after, but it all just fell away. It has established an unhelpful reputation of uncommunicativeness though.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Anyway, back to the trading update.

BE11:44am

Cazenove can summarise what's little has been said.

BE11:45am

Aveva provided an inline Q1 trading statement with limited details, but suggesting that market trends remained steady from last year. Revenues should again be H2 weighted. The statement read: “Full year outlook remaining in line with the Board’s expectations”, and we note that company consensus (of 9 analysts) is for FY18 revenues of £225m, PBT of £59m and adj. EPS of 72.3p.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

No trend changes in Q1. We recap trends from the end of last year:
O&G (around 45% of revs) demand remained weak with EPS customers being impacted by the c.40% capex reductions within the O&G market overall; Marine (approx. 20% of revs) seemed slightly better in Q1, but ship orders did fall last year due to over-capacity in world fleets; Power (approx. 15-20% of revs) saw positive market trends with Aveva gaining share, especially in North America; Petrochem and Chemical (approx. 10% of revs) saw stable market conditions with ongoing investments in Asia and Aveva winning new OO customers; and Other Markets (approx. 10% of revs) including mining, paper, pulp and pharmaceutical.

BE11:46am

We have made minor updates to FX assumptions and increased the tax rate to around 21.5% (we had previously decelerated the tax rate a little too quickly). We are now modelling FY18 revenues of £228m, PBT of £61m and adjusted diluted EPS of 74p.

Shares are trading on 25x calendarised 2018 PE and 17x EV/EBITDA.

BE11:46am

17x EV/EBITDA isn't strikingly cheap, is it?

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Just an observation, not advice. Good luck to all holders.

undefined
PM11:47am

This Apple / Imagination stuff mentioned on the right...

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Stems from this Bloomberg story

PM11:47am

https://www.bloomb...n-contract-dispute

PM11:48am

As littleclenches notes

11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@Blue horseshoe: you might not have noticed, but as well as providing a handy forum for ramps we do typing and stuff on this side of the page.)

PM11:48am

Does seem quite damaging

PM11:49am

Apple directly contradicting them on the timeline

11:49 am
Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 150.00, down 7.25 (-4.61%), High: 159.25, Low: 144.75, Volume: 1.69m
BE11:49am

Yep. Though I guess there was not much chance of this not turning into acrimony.

PM11:49am

true

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Whoever eventually buys Imagination -- assuming anyone does -- knows the Apple exposure is 99% certain to be litigation rather than a dormant billion-dollar contract.

BE11:51am

Let me cut back to an old Credit Suisse note to talk about the value here, or otherwise.

BE11:52am

Post 2HFY17 results, we adjust our revenue estimates up by 3-7% for FY18-FY20 driven mainly by higher volumes for both PowerVR and MIPS. However, with Apple accounting for ~45% of IMG sales and Apple deciding to stop payments during 2018 or early 2019 given ongoing dispute, we estimate that OMs will head back to 20% loss in FY20 vs. 20% profit in FY17. Given the uncertainty arising from the Apple dispute, IMG is already engaged in the formal sale of the whole company with multiple bidders showing interest. We continue to believe that IMG has strategic assets (IP and technology) especially around graphics, which should generate a good level of interest from bidders. As such, we reiterate our Neutral rating but raise our TP to 165p (vs. 100p previously).

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Having delivered £27.5mn of cost savings, IMG managed to turn around OM from 17% loss in FY16 to 20% profit in FY17. However, if we were to assume that IMG loses 60% of Apple business in FY19 before going to zero in FY20, we estimate that IMG will head to 20% OM loss in FY20, thereby making the company unsustainable without external funding. Further, given its strong suite of GPU related IP and patents, we believe there could be interest from multiple semi companies esp. with exposure to mobile and automotive given its importance around AR/VR (augmented/virtual reality) and autonomous driving.

BE11:53am

And yes indeed, @Guidinghand, if there is an issue over timely disclosure of material information to the market then the consequences would be extreme.

BE11:54am

But that's not something we can speculate on.

11:54 am
undefined
BE11:55am

So, Cape .............

Cape PLC (CIU:LSE): Last: 264.50, up 83.25 (+45.93%), High: 268.00, Low: 262.00, Volume: 7.57m
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Recommended 265p cash offer.

BE11:57am

Altrad the buyer. Cash offer at £332m in total.

BE11:57am

The ~46% premium looks impressive, sure, but that's post a terrible run.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

Counter possible? Plausibly. Though it's not obvious.

BE11:58am

Here's RBC ....

BE11:58am

.... which only started coverage of Cape on Tuesday.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

With an outperform rating.

BE11:58am

The Cape Directors intend to recommend the offer to shareholders and irrevocable undertakings have been received from ~22.1m cape shares representing
~18.2% of shares in issue. The offer will be conditional upon acceptances being received from not less than 90% of shares, as well as the required Merger
Control Clearances. We expect the deal to be approved by shareholders and do not anticipate a rival bid. 
Altrad is an industrial services company providing scaffolding and light construction equipment in the civil and industrial sectors with a history of growth through
acquisitions. The two companies have complementary geographic and product mixes; the combination would create a larger multi-disciplinary industrial services
leader. Altrad will finance the acquisition with a new debt facility.

BE12:00pm

Cape, by memory, was beaten down because of its asbestos exposure right?

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Which has largely been resolved, or at least appears to be capped.

BE12:00pm

Here's the valuation stuff from RBC on Tuesday, to help explain the attraction here.

BE12:01pm

Cape is trading on FY18E PE and EV/EBITDA multiples of
6.7x and 4.3x, materially below its industrial and oilfield services peers. Following the resolutions of both lawsuits, we believe the material financial uncertainty has been resolved and Cape should trade on multiples higher than its five-year averages. As the majority of Cape’s revenues are derived from multi-year contracts, we have also included a DCF valuation as part of our price target. Our price target of 290p/ share implies FY18E P/E of 10.5x, and EV/EBITDA of 6.3x, compared to the peer group averages of 16.1x and 6.8x.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

............. And that, I think, is us for the week.

BE12:03pm

Paul's already taken an early lunch and I've a story to chase, so we should probably knock off.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Back on Monday. Enjoy the sun. Afternoon all.

PM11:23am

(We've talked in the past about how, as financial journalists, we are probably in a decent position to call the odds on other journalist's bid stories. ie if it's X at Y publication, it is probably true, etc. And that we could find a way of monetising this... since the markets often move on a story regardless of providence...)
